units.title: Reading: Startup culture and building a startup
units.description: Read a text about startup culture, four steps to build a startup, and incubators vs accelerators.

text.description: A short text about startup culture and the steps to build a startup.

content_data.content_text:
Did you ever dream of building your own startup? Even if you didn’t, startup mentality and startup culture are popular in the tech world.

Many startups have values that even big businesses are trying to adopt: quickly adapting to change; demanding high involvement; open, honest and transparent relationships; thinking outside the box and finding innovative, cost-effective solutions.

If you’re planning on creating your own business, thinking like an entrepreneur can help your personal development and career growth.

Four steps for building a startup:
1) Develop a vision for your product. Ask yourself what customer pain point you can solve, which gaps in the market you can fill, whether your solution is elegant and scalable, and whether you can pivot if you have to.
2) Put together a great team. As a leader, you need to be in charge of hiring and bring people on board who match the company and share motivation and passion.
3) Think about the logistics. Consider your location, expenses and annual budget. Incubators can help with low-cost equipment, mentorship, marketing/PR, pitching, accommodation and networking.
4) Prepare your pitch. Pitching is delivering a concise, informative speech about yourself, your product or your company to people who can fund and mentor you.

Extra: Incubators help startups discover an idea and create a business plan. Accelerators help startups with an existing MVP to grow and develop quicker.

organization that helps startups with an MVP scale faster

units.title: Grammar: Past Simple vs Present Perfect
units.description: Learn when to use Past Simple vs Present Perfect and practice with exercises from the lesson.

explanation.text: Use Past Simple for finished time in the past (yesterday, last week, in 2016). Use Present Perfect for unfinished time or life experience up to now (ever/never/just/already/yet, for/since).
examples: I worked in an electronics store when I was a student. (Past Simple)
I have worked as a software engineer at this company for 6 years. (Present Perfect)
Have you ever tried Voice UI? (Present Perfect)

activities.prompt: Choose the correct form (Past Simple or Present Perfect).

items.question: I ______ any new books recently.
Two of my teammates ______ the company last week.
We ______ a lot of time fixing this issue last night.
______ a competition?
We ______ the sprint on Friday.
Who is this guy? I ______ him before.
I ______ to the USA.
Jeff isn’t at the office this week. He ______ on a business trip.
We ______ on a huge conference.

items.sentence: I have been interested in technology ______ I was a child.
We can trust Jim with it, he has worked in this area ______ six years now.
They have been in this meeting room ______ 3 hours and they haven’t finished yet.
He has lived in Ireland ______ over 5 years now ______ he started working at Google.
He’s my best friend, I have known him ______ school.
Tom hasn’t been that much fun ______ he got married.

activities.prompt:
Put the verbs in brackets into the correct tense (Past Simple or Present Perfect):
1) We (have) a lot of tasks last night. I (come) home at midnight.
2) He (never/work) in this position before.
3) He (send) me the report yet.
4) I (work) at this company for 3 years. (I still work here).
5) I (work) at this company for 3 years. (I don’t work here anymore).
6) — (you/ever/be) to California? — Yes, I (be) there two years ago.

llmCheck.systemPrompt: You are a grammar tutor. The student conjugates verbs using Past Simple vs Present Perfect. 1) Score 0-6 (one point per sentence block). 2) Provide the correct answers. 3) Correct 1-2 most important errors briefly.

units.title: Speaking & Soft Skills: Sales pitch
units.description: Practice presenting your company or product using a clear pitch structure.

questions.modelAnswer: I'm a product manager at a small startup.
We help small teams manage tasks and communicate clearly.

questions.prompt: What’s the value proposition? (what you do better)
questions.modelAnswer: We make onboarding faster with templates and automation.

questions.prompt: Grab attention: add one fact, story or statistic.
questions.modelAnswer: Over 40% of teams fail to onboard users properly—our product fixes that.

llmCheck.systemPrompt: You are a friendly English-speaking colleague. The student delivers a short sales pitch in 4 parts. 1) Give short feedback on clarity and persuasiveness. 2) Correct up to 3 mistakes. 3) Suggest 3 stronger phrases. Keep it short.

activities.prompt: Role-play: you meet a potential mentor/investor. Deliver a concise pitch about your startup idea and answer follow-up questions.

turns.modelAnswer: I'm building a tool that helps teams create better pitch decks.

turns.text: What customer pain point do you solve?

turns.modelAnswer: Teams waste time and lose investors because their pitch is unclear.
We use templates and AI feedback to keep the pitch concise.

turns.text: What do you need next: money, mentorship, or partners?

turns.modelAnswer: I need mentorship and introductions to early customers.

llmCheck.systemPrompt: You are a mentor/investor. Have a short conversation (7-10 turns) about the student’s startup pitch. Ask follow-up questions about team, market, and next steps. After the role-play, provide: 1) 2 strengths, 2) up to 3 corrections, 3) 2 actionable tips. Simple English.

units.title: Glossary of Technical words
units.description: Key startup and business words commonly used in the tech industry.

glossary.definition: A newly established business. A software startup valued at more than one billion dollars is called a "unicorn", implying that such cases are extremely rare.
An owner of shares in a company.
An organization that supports and develops early-stage companies.
An organization that provides startups with support services and funding opportunities.
A presentation used to pitch a business idea or company, usually to investors.
A set of programming code that enables data transmission between software products.
The highest-ranking executive in a company, responsible for major managerial decisions.
A product version with just enough features to be usable by early customers.
A type of financing that investors provide to startups and small businesses.
To start and grow a business using minimal financial resources.
To increase the production capacity or growth of a company or system.
An inwordediary who buys goods from producers and sells them to retailers or consumers.
